revision.text:
==Colors== There are six colors of gems, with a seventh combo-gem-color [[File:5gem.png|35px]] for when 5 gems are matched together...
There are two styles of gems, one for the character matching-game and one for the ship matching-game...
All of the gems are listed below...
Logo at beginning: [[File:White.png|25px]][[File:Red.png|25px]][[File:Orange.png|25px]][[File:5gem.png|25px]][[File:Purple.png|25px]][[File:Yellow.png|25px]][[File:Blue.png|25px]] misses [[File:Hidden-Green.png|25px]]
ships have changes in [[File:White-ship.png|50px]][[File:Red-ship.png|50px]][[File:Green-ship.png|50px]] and [[File:Purple-ship.png|50px]]
[[CrewAll|Crew members]] can have skills that are boosted using each of the primary six colors - specifically: {{Gem|r}}, {{Gem|w}}, {{Gem|b}}, {{Gem|o}}, {{Gem|y}}, amd {{Gem|p}}. OTOH, ships only have features for the colors {{Gem|b}}, {{Gem|o}}, {{Gem|y}}, and {{Gem|q}} since red, green, and white are used for battle. [[Category:Colors]]

'''''{{PAGENAME}}''''' are one of the most fun aspects of many games, including stwog. On this page, we will list several of the simple-pages that list collections of some type. For a possibly more-useful listing, you could try using the ''[[:Category:Collections |Collections category]]'' to see if there is more-than-one page listed (which is where you'd end up if you'd clicked on the ''Collections/Collections'' submenu). Lastly, if you'd like to ''Talk'' about collections in stwog then maybe visit the [[Talk:Collections |Talk subpage]]...
* '''[[Tips WYW |Tips]]''' that are shown '''while you are waiting''' (WYW) for the gem mini-game to load * '''[[Questions |Questions]]''' about the game - an ongoing list... * '''[[Hero table]]''' which would be nice to have auto-populating... * '''[[Level50]]''' which groups all the tier-1 max pages... [[Category:Collections]]

[[File:Placeholder|video|right|300px]] [[File:Placeholder|right|300px]] Alliances are a way to help increase your rank within the game. A new player does not appear to be able to join an alliance until after a set amount of time (or possibly a number of games) has elapsed. There is also a Forum to discuss alliances, which never really took-off and which (since the game is ending soon) will not be too important now at [[Board:Alliances]]...
==Menu headings==
* Alliance * Top Alliances * Search
==Why would you want to join an alliance?==
By joining an alliance, you and your teammates are able to combine resources and reap the rewards of doing so. In particular, the alliance itself will be ranked for the time-limited Arenas. Once the Arena ends, all of the members of the alliance will receive a payout based on their overall-placement. The higher the members place in the Arena, the better the rewards. [[Category:Gameplay]]

==Glossary==
===''''' C '''''===
===='''Color'''==== Color can refer to a game-gem, a crew-skill, or a ship-feature - depending upon context. There is also a template named color ({{T|Color}}) which might be useful... ===='''Crew or Character'''==== Crew are the human (or other living-race) beings in the game. Crew or characters are held in one area of the game - as opposed to Starships. * Crew members typically have Skills (also called Abilities or Powers) * Crew members follow the Tier and Level structure
===''''' F '''''===
===='''Features'''==== Features are the extra powers that a Starship has (typically 3 color features are available) which are used inside the Starship Mini-game. A feature becomes activated by matching 6 to 15 gems of that color during the mini-game. Once activated, that feature can be used (before your turn) to boost-damage, recover-health, rearrange-the-board, etc. During the Starship Mini-game, the colors Red, Green, and White will activate Torpedos, Phasers, and Shields - so they are not used for Features to avoid double-duty. Thus, there are only 4 Colors used for Starship Features: Orange, Yellow, Blue, and Purple.
===''''' L '''''===
===='''Level'''==== Level is the numerical ranking of a Crew member or Starship. Typically, the levels start at 1 and increase thru the player spending crystals or coins. Eventually, a maximum Level is reached for the Tier; but before that happens, there are typically many sub-Tier barriers. Sub-Tier barriers on the Levels typically require Evolving the character or ship.
===''''' S '''''===
===='''Skills'''==== Skills are the extra powers that a Character has (typically 3 color skills are available) which are used inside the Character Mini-game. A skill becomes activated by matching 6 to 15 gems of that color during the mini-game. Once activated, that skill can be used (before your turn) to boost-damage or recover-health or rearrange-the-board or ... The color green is not used in the Character Mini-game. Thus, there are 6 Colors used for Character Skills: Red, Orange, Yellow, White, Blue, and Purple. ===='''Starships or Ships'''==== Starships are the mechanical (or non-living) containers for the Crew inside the game. Ships are held in a second area of the game - as opposed to Crew members. * Starships can contain Crew members * Starships can contain Weapons (offensive [photon-torpedos] or defensive [shields]) which will increase their Abilities or Powers * Starships followv the Tier and Level structure.
===''''' T '''''===
===='''Tier'''==== Tier is the word used to categorize Crew and Starships. Current Tiers are 1, 2, and 3. # Tier-1 characters and ships are the basic starter items in the game. They typically start and Level 1 and are able to upgrade (eventually) to Level 49 or 50. # Tier-2 characters and ships are occasional reward items in the game. As the player advances and gets Recruit possibilities, the basic Packs will drop Tier-1 and Tier-2 items. They start at Level 10 and upgrade (eventually) to Level 94 or 95. # Tier-3 characters and ships are only available with extended playing or PTW possibilities. Another way to get these items is through Alliance rewards after Events or Arena contests end. They start at Level 40 and upgrade (eventually) to Level 165, I believe. [[Category:Gameplay]]

=Questions= ==Q by/about Time== ===History=== * When did this game get released ? : sept 2015 according to [http://memory-beta.wikia.com/wiki/Star_Trek_Wrath_of_Gems this]... * Is there any historical information about stuff that happened before this wikia got started in Aug-2016 ? : the game-maker's website has a list of their current and old [http://startrekwrathofgems.generamobile.com/category/news/ NEWS]...
===Current=== * What events are active today ? : try the [[:Board:News and Announcements]] which i ''was'' keeping up... nowadays, i just put quick-links to new-events on the [[:project:Calendar]] page... * What arenas are active today ? : these change too-often/fast for me to list... someone wanna volunteer ? ===Future=== * What new starships/characters are coming ? : these usually show up as arena-title-characters or on genera's website... nowadays, i also have a [[:project:spoilers]] page... * What new events/arenas/stories are coming ?
==Q by/about Game== * What does the word ''XYZ'' mean ? : there is a [[Glossary]] here that might help - feel free to add to it ! * What is the point of this game ? : for users, there are 3 basic ideas: :: diversion - it is fun to play a simple gem-match game occasionally :: collection - it is fun to collect all the characters and starships :: competition - it is fun to battle against others or yourself inside the game : for the companies, it is almost always about making money somehow... * Does it cost any money ? : FTP - no, it is free-to-play : PTW - maybe, it is pay-to-win because it takes a long-time to make progress without spending any $$ * Does it require that i join something ? : not officially, but if you are wanting to have a backup of your progress - then you will want to either login with Facebook or Google_+ to cloud-save or link your account... * Are there links to other places for information ? : [http://memory-beta.wikia.com/wiki/Star_Trek_Wrath_of_Gems Memory Beta] : [http://startrekwrathofgems.generamobile.com/ Genera website (author)]
==Q by/about Playing== * Are there any youtube videos ? ** [https://youtu.be/3J_4-3ZxOys THIS] is the official stwog-trailer from Genera Games and CBS-Interactive... ** [https://youtu.be/aRV-0GcVAUA THIS] is an ad from Trekyards... ** [https://www.youtube.com/results?search_query=Star+Trek+Wrath+of+Gems HERE] is your handy-dandy search results from youtube, which might be helpful... * Where should I write to ask for help if there are problems inside the game ? ** in-game, go to settings->Customer Support... once you write your first comment/question - it looks like it sets up a chat-area... ** note-to-self, i should get screenshots and post them over at [[Main Menu]] - i didnt even pay attention to the gear-settings-area until i needed it for this function... ** oob - these are not recommended for simple things like missing-a-weapon, but might be useful for more-general contact... *** there is a contact form online at their website, [https://generagames.com/contact/ HERE]... *** their direct email address (from same page) is: support [AT] generagames [DOT] com... ** remember, the company is located in spain - so business hours for them may not match the hours for you (like in the usa or japan or ...) - so be patient... * etc...
==Q by/about Wikia== ===General=== * How do I edit something here ? : use the user-sandboxes (which i might notve setup - yet a/o correctly...lol) : there are lots of how-to-edit pages: ::# see: [http://community.wikia.com/wiki/Editing_101 how-to-edit] community-central ::# see: [[w:c:layton:Help:Editing |how-to-edit]] layton ::# see: [[w:c:dungeonlink:Project:Hero_data |how-to-edit]] dungeon-hero ::# see: [[:Help:Edit |how-to-edit]] local ::: aka [http://community.wikia.com/wiki/Help:Shared_help shared help] * How can I become a great editor ? : [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Be_bold be bold] and [http://community.wikia.com/wiki/Wikia_University learn] ===Specific to stwog=== * How is this wikia organized ? : im gonna try to setup a goals-page which will explain how i hope to get information in a useful form for use here... tbd... * What steps are needed to successfully add a new character i see in the game ? :# read [http://stwog.wikia.com/wiki/Thread:1160 This thread] :# see if they already have a character-code [[Module:Charactercodes/data]] ::* if not, then add a new one... ::* if so, then why didnt you see them here ? :::: mistake in character-list ? :::: mistake in character-page ? * What steps are needed to add a new level ?
===Feedback=== * Is there a forum for discussions ? * Should I just mention an item on a user's or any page's '''Talk'''-subpage ? [[Category:Gameplay]]

{{Improve}} ==General Strategy== These are strategies that hold-true regardless of gameplay-styles, but are important to STWOG... ===Be slow=== * Since there is a "healing" aspect to many of the game-elements, and that healing depends upon physical wall-time expiring, it is actually better to be a SLOW player than a fast one... ===Accept the bugs=== * This game was/is not coded perfectly... There have been many occasions that i was shaking my head and saying WTF at the screen... in my case, usually the errors worked out in my favor - but occasionally it did not... try to be zen about it... * I used to work in software development and we had a fun-expression: "It is NOT a bug, it is a FEATURE..." we used whenever something unexpected happened in our software... ===Try picking on weaker opponents=== * If you are given the chance to battle someone/something that is significantly weaker than you - take it... ===Bail out if you are gonna Lose=== * Since there is no real penalty for the game "crashing", you can use that to your advantage... ** If you are about to lose an Arena-battle, then just jump out of the game and kill-it from your task-manager (ie: crash)... The next time you start the game/app it will put you right back at a fresh-try against your opponent... ** This can work in Event-battles also, however i am not sure whether you would lose any trophy points like in Arenas... also, the clock-timer did not reset if you retried directly after a loss - so bailing out of the game might change your points-awarded (to more, actually) if you were re-playing a battle... * This was mentioned elsewhere [https://stwog.wikia.com/wiki/Events_in_general#.27Thermometer.27_Prizes LINK] but it was oftentimes useful to bail out of the prize-awards if you were unsure whether you wanted to collect them just-then... ===Read the [[Tips WYW]]=== * The tips do repeat a fair amount and have a fair number of general comments, BUT... * The tips you receive that are specific, will be specific for your upcoming battle or mode - namely: Crew, Ship, or Diplomacy... * The tips also might remind you of strategies that you have optimized upon during your specific gameplay... For instance, there is one about "always attack the strongest opponent first" - but when there are 3 characters to battle i find that targeting the RIGHT-most character (of any two equal-level) is more effective for my gameplay-style...
==Collection Strategy== === The Numbers === * The bare-minimum number of characters and starships you will ever need is 6 and 2... Once you have decided WHICH ones you like - the truth is you could probably live with ''only'' those 6 character and 2 ship slots... ** NB: There are currently only two characters who have 3-possible-versions... Thus, you could conceivably have the following teams: *** All-Worf: [[CN/WF]] [[CN/CWF]] [[CN/SWF]] *** All-Uhura: [[CO/NU]] [[CO/CNU]] [[CO/ANU]] ** As described above, each differently tiered (star) character is independent and levels-up on its own terms... * Once upon a time, it was probably possible to collect a character TWICE - but I have never actually played against any Crew-team that had more than 3 characters... ** The reason I believe that it used to be possible is because I have seen a 4-player team occasionally inside the Alliance-listings... ** I assume that my viewing is actually just a '''BUG''' of the viewing process, rather than a bug that is actually playable for that player... * The Recruit Area will hold any/all ships or characters for a week... ** Unfortunately, as a newer player, the game is fairly boring and so it is sometimes easy to let this time-of-holding, '''EXPIRE'''... ** If you do not plan on using any of the recruited characters, it is very beneficial to sell them for the crystals-earned... ** Way back when, I think I did let them expire and I think that by-doing-so - I was not given any crystals for their sale... {{color|red|You have been warned}} * After spending some gold on single expansion slots for either characters or starships, the cost for further expansion-slots increases (but not doubles) so you can buy slots 2-at-a-time... ** The single-slot costs are: [[Tbd...]] ** The double-slots costs are: *** Crew: {{P|g|600|g}} *** Starship {{P|g|700|g}} === The Choices === * Most newer players will just collect/upgrade whatever characters/starships they stumble-across normally ** Except for some rare exceptions, it is almost always more-beneficial to collect/upgrade higher tiered crew/ships... *** The notable exceptions are: **** [[Tbd...]] should link to crew-team preferences by-player... **** [[Tbd...]] should link to ships prefs by-player... *** The reason to go for higher tiers is to play against harder opponents and thus receive higher rewards... ** For Events, it is entirely possible to complete all levels of every event (even Hard.Legendary) using three [[Level50|Tier 1]] maxxed-out characters and a ship... ** For Arenas, it becomes impossible to win beyond certain-limits without having higher-tiered/higher-levelled items... * There are some characters/ships that are higher-probability to receive for various reasons... If you are a newer player, these higher-probability character recruitments are critical to move forward in the game... Some of my personal-experiences are as follows: ** If you use the '''WHEEL''' a lot, the characters you receive are fairly consistent after awhile... *** [[:Category:Romulan]] - usually [[Terrhea]], [[D'Aindal]], and [[T'Vralai]] *** ?-prize-bonus: [[S'Fangudl]], [[DaiMon Tarr]] *** Earlier (iirc) it included [[Ameh]], [[Ensign Chekov]], [[Lt. Sulu]] and [[Lt. Uhura]] *** Earlier ?-prizes: [[Cmdr. McCoy]], ** The [[Main Menu#Second Row|wheel]] never has given away a ship, afaict... ** Depending upon which Events you play (and how far you get), you can receive the following characters/ships fairly easily... *** Ships: [[Hideki]], [[Galor]], [[Original Enterprise]], [[Next Enterprise]], [[Klingon bop]], [[Romulan bop]] ** Depending upon which Storyline you start with (and how far you go thru the story), you will receive the following characters/ships... *** [[:Category:TOS Ship]] - {{ships|oae|4}}, {{ships|okb|4}}, {{ships|orb|2}}, *** [[:Category:TOS Crew]] - 2*{{nowrap|[[Mister Scott]]}}, 2*{{nowrap|[[Lt. Uhura]]}}, {{nowrap|[[Captain Kirk]]}}, 2*{{nowrap|[[Lt. Sulu]]}}, 2*{{nowrap|[[Mister Spock]]}}, 2*{{nowrap|[[Doctor McCoy]]}}, 2*{{nowrap|[[Ensign Chekov]]}} *** [[:Category:TNG Ship]] - {{ships|nae|4}}, {{ships|nkv|5}}, {{ships|nch|3}}, *** [[:Category:TNG Crew]] - 2*{{nowrap|[[Cmdr. Riker]]}}, 2*{{nowrap|[[Lt. La Forge]]}}, 2*{{nowrap|[[Captain Picard]]}}, 2*{{nowrap|[[Lt. Data]]}}, {{nowrap|[[Lt. Worf]]}}, 2*{{nowrap|[[Counselor Troi]]}}, 2*{{nowrap|[[Dr. Beverly Crusher]]}}, *** You will also get lots of basic/blue recruitment packs, both TNG and TOS which will adjust the lists given above by random-amounts of extra characters/starships...
==Ship Game Strategy== [[File:Ship-game.png|thumb|bottom-right|Stylized Ship Game showing matching-gem battlefield with enterprise crossing overlay]] * You do not need to have a perfectly repaired (100%) ship to start a battle...
==Crew Game Strategy== [[File:Crew-game.png|thumb|top-right|Stylized Crew Game shown in background while Spock and Worf fire phasers in forefront]] * You do not need to have a perfectly healthy (100%) crew to start a battle... * You do not need to have all three crew-slots filled to start a battle... * However, you DO need to have each of your crew-slots filled with character at greater-than-25% health to start a battle... At least, I got a message saying that when one of my crew members was too-weak and i had forgotten to heal him...
==Diplomacy Strategy== * You do not need to have a perfectly healthy (100%) character to start a battle... [[Category:Gameplay]]

==Tiers==
So far there are only three tiers of characters and/or starships available... However, the google-+ system indicates that there is a bonus to getting a tier-4 ship/crew...
===Tier 1=== Starts at Level-1 and Upgrades/Evolves thru a max of [[Level50|Level-50]].
Used for Crew and Starships with the following subpages for details: * [[Test Hero Level 1 type]] & [[Test Ship Level 1 type]]
===Tier 2=== Starts at Level-10 and Upgrades/Evolves thru a max of [[Level95|Level-95]]. Note, passes thru [[Level 50]] after 10-Evolutions.
Used for Crew and Starships with the following subpages for details: * [[Test Hero Level 2 type]] & [[Test Ship Level 2 type]]
===Tier 3=== Starts at Level-40 and Upgrades/Evolves thru a max of [[Level165|Level-165]]. Note, passes thru [[Level 50]] after 3-Evolutions and hits [[Level 95]] just-before 9-Evolutions (which happens at Level-96).
Used for Crew and Starships with the following subpages for details: * [[Test Hero Level 3 type]] & [[Test Ship Level 3 type]]
===Tier 3.5=== A weird (not really Tier-4) subset of Tier-3...
nb - for a sortable-chart, try the template {{T|TiermaxALL}}

== Types == There are two ''primary'' types of currency used in-game, [[File:Currency-dilithiums.png|30px]] dilithium crystals (purple[[File:Currency-dilithium.png|20px]]) and [[File:Currency-coins.png|30px]] coins (gold[[File:Currency-coin.png|20px]]). Typically, the crystals are used to increase the level of a character or starship. The coins are used to upgrade/evolve a character or starship and to buy other specialized items. Even though coins are normally used for upgrades, a more economical way to upgrade is to recruit another copy of the same character or starship. The recruit button changes to an upgrade-button which allows another set of levels to be unlocked (evolved) when used. Even though coins can purchase items from the Archive, it is often possible to win the items in other ways. A common theme in the game is to have an Event to play (eg Borg-Cube-1) for a week or so. Once that event is complete, then that item will be available for sale in the Archive for a few days (eg Cube-1 has a red ribbon with bow in Archive signifying sale). The purchase price is oftentimes very high (eg 3000 coins). However, if you are very persistent and maybe even lucky, then during the original event you can keep playing against opponenets until you win that same character as a prize. Also, at the conclusion of the event, your alliance could also be rewarded with that item. Coins are the only means to do the following specialized tasks. # Purchase more Crew member slots for characters # Purchase more Stardock slots for starships Extra Crew and Stardock slots become critical the longer you play so that you can collect and upgrade without losing your already-upgraded items... === Real World Money === Inside the game, you can [http://www.urbandictionary.com/define.php?term=PTW PTW] by purchasing coins/gold and.or dilithium/xtals using the [[Main Menu#Top Row|plus sign icon]]... This takes you to the Shop-page where for actual-money you can purchase (asof 2017-08-18): * Coins [[File:Currency-coins.png|20px]] ** Pack-1 of 200 for $1.99 ** Pack-2 of 600 for $4.99 ** Pack-3 of 2,900 for $19.99 ** Pack-4 of 8,500 for $49.99 ** Pack-5 of 20,000 for $99.99 * Dilithium [[File:Currency-dilithiums.png|20px]] ** Pack-1 of 1250 for $1.99 ** Pack-2 of 3300 for $4.99 ** Pack-3 of 14,000 for $19.99 ** Pack-4 of 39,000 for $49.99 ** Pack-5 of 80,000 for $99.99 === In-Game Currencies === Besides the above-mentioned gold and dilithium, there are other currencies used inside the game... * {{p|b|1|b}} ** This buys you a chance of recruiting a single character (or starship)... ** These chances are either.or {{Itng}} {{Itos}} depending upon where the items was won... * {{p|r|1|r}} ** This buys you a 5-card recruitment chance... ** The odds of getting a [[Tiers|Tier-2]] character or starship are higher... * {{p|y|1|y}} ** This buys you a 10-card recruitment chance... ** The odds of getting a [[Tiers|Tier-3]] character or starship are higher... * {{p|w|1|w}} ** This buys you the ability to fixup a ship instantly, just before using that same-ship in a game... ** Useful so that you do not need to wait for a significant amount of wall-time to expire, while the ship self-heals... * {{p|h|1|h}} ** Heals a character instantly... ** Similar to wrenches, except if you have 3 team-members on a Crew-fight - you might need to spend 3 healths to heal them all == Cost Tables == Typically, for tier-XX characters - the cost for each level-upgrade rises by a consistent amount (eg tier-1 crew adds 50 crystals). This allows us to create a simple table to calculate costs... == Stages == for the sake if discussion, we can specify four stages of a player's gameplay [http://yukaichou.com/gamification-examples/experience-phases-game/ Link]: # Beginner / Discovery ## Played less than 10 hours total... ## Have not played with both TOS and TNG characters... # Novice / Onboarding ## Played 10 to 100 hours total... ## Have connected a Google or Facebook account to avoid losing progress... ## Have finished enough of both [[:Category:Story TOS]] and [[:Category:Story TNG]] that [[Arena Sequence]] and [[Events Sequence]] games are available... ## Are getting bored with the '''Grind''' and have encountered several of the bugs/quirks of the game... ## Have not yet purchased extra Character or Starship slots for their inventory... ## Starting to choose their preferred upgrades and style of play... ## Want to know if there are shortcuts to winning and/or specific Crew or Ships that are the "best"... ### Need to discover the [[Alliance Area]] ### Can look at better players (and their chosen teams) for ideas and [[Strategy]] # Regular / Scaffolding ## Played 100 to 1000 hours total... ## Have completed both Story sequences... ## Have played in several Arenas and/or Events... ## Have purchased extra Characters, Starships, and/or Slots for their inventory... ## Have accepted the '''Grind''' and the '''Bugs''' (see Trivia sections)... ## Want to join better [[Alliances]] to enable faster progress... ### Need to push every touch-area to optimize shortcuts... ### Can now decide what longer-term goals they want to pursue for their "wins"... # Expert / Endgame ## Played over 1000 hours total... ## Have seen all the Events at least once... ## Have upgraded at least 3 Tier-1 characters and 1 Tier-1 starship to [[Level50]]... ## Have upgraded at least 1 Tier-2 character or starship to [[Level95]]... ## Have received Tier-3 characters or starships... ## tbd...
=== Beginner Stage === keep playing...
=== Novice Stage === choose your teams...
=== Regular Stage === upgrade crew/ships...
=== Expert Stage === help newer folks...

== Summary == This page is a place to collect commentary that would normally be placed onto each individual Event-page, but becomes repetitive if done so... Each '''[[:Category:Events| event ]]''' can thus contain links to this page for further commentary after a brief description...
== Format Descriptions == === Three Versions === As mentioned in {{t|EventText02}} the usual place to discuss the three versions, is when describing the difficulty-ratings. {{color|blue|Easy}}, {{color|yellow|Normal}}, and ''eventually'' {{color|purple|Legendary}} missions each have their own starting-screen from the [[Events Sequence]] for that-titled event.
Another set-of-three versions are the three types of Gameplay Styles. {{color|orange|Crew battles [C]}}, {{color|magenta|Ship battles [S]}}, and {{color|grey|Diplomacy battles [D]}} used throughout STWOG...
A third set-of-three versions are the prizes available for winning. First, there are the '''''mission''''' prizes awarded immediately after each win. Usually there are 3 or 4 of these prizes per mission. These prizes require replaying each mission four times. Second, there are the '''''points''''' prizes which are gained by accumulating points for completing the missions. These points-prizes are awarded (as points accumulate) alongside the mission-prizes immediately. To receive the highest-points prizes usually requires some strategy and replaying of some missions ''more'' than the typical four times. And lastly, there are the '''''series''''' prizes which are gained near or after the conclusion of the week-long (or 2-wk) event.
=== Storyline === The descriptions of the storyline (in the chart) are just the summary-comments for each mission. The bonus-missions do not advance the storyline, so do not have comments. Any regular missions, when played, will have cut-scenes that flesh out the details of the story. These cut-scenes will help to setup the type of Gameplay required for that mission. Also, the icons are informative and adjust (in realtime) as you play the missions to help you determine your progress.
* {{color|orange|C/Character-silhouette}} = Crew combat (1/2/3 against 1/2/3 characters) * {{color|grey|D/Diplomacy dots+lines}} = Do-it-yourself (3 colors Green vs 3 colors Red) * {{color|magenta|S/Starship icon}} = Space battle (ship against ship)
The types are represented by the icon beside/inside the glowing circle. If the mission is still locked, the icon is a padlock. The locks are removed and replaced with the C/D/S icons once the timer (to start) has expired and.or the previous missions (following the storyline) are complete. As each mission is completed, the dots (above that mission-icon) will brighten to represent having received that prize. Unfortunately, there are often bugs with the dots that require you to enter the mission-itself to confirm. Also, once a mission has been completed the requisite 4 times, its circle will change from dim-yellow to Full-Yellow (bonus) or from blue to Full-Green (storyline).
While it is usually helpful to just glance at the icons.and.dots to see if you have received all the prizes - a more accurate assessment is to look at the top for the summary. If you see a 20/20 (for missions completed at least once) and a 80/80 (for prizes received from the missions), then you can be fairly sure you have received all of the '''''mission''''' prizes for that event.
=== Enemies === Typically, the enemies you will face in each mission will stay the same. What will change is the evolution.level of the enemy, which will depend upon the difficulty of the series played. {{color|blue|Easy}} and {{color|yellow|normal.medium}} enemies should never require the player to need anything higher than [[Level50|tier 1 max]] characters or starships to defeat them. {{color|purple|Legendary.hard}} enemies stay below [[Level95|tier 2 max]] and '''can''' (thru persistence and luck) be beaten with an appropriate Level 50 character or starship.
For the missions that are {{color|orange|character battles [C]}}, each character.opponent is listed in its own sub-area within the mission (separated by a line). For the {{color|magenta|starship battles [S]}}, the information includes any listed-crew or listed-weapons additions. And lastly for the {{color|grey|diplomacy trials [D]}}, the opponent color-strengths are listed which can be mapped against the color-hexagon.
=== Scoring === The scoring chart shows all of the individual '''''mission''''' prizes that you can win, along with the amount of points earned. The points are auto-calculated at +25 per-level for Easy, +50 per-level for Normal, and +75 per-level for Legendary.
As mentioned at [[Strategy]], there is an important issue concerning points: the Level-points listed are the max-amount of points possible per-win. Each time you play a specific-level, the points you can earn to '''REplay''' that same-level drops by half - with a 1 hr timer attached. For fastest-play you can play the same level immediately 4 times in a row, but you would only earn 1.0 + 0.5 + 0.25 + 0.125 = 1.875 times the points for your overall score. For best-points, you can play the same-level those same four times but with at least 1-hour wall-time gaps, and you would earn 4 times the points for overall score. Thus, you can earn more-than-double (4 vs. 1.9) the points by delaying your replays of a level.
Using the example of 12 missions and 8 bonus-missions, we would have 20 total missions. The points for winning the first-mission would be 25 for Easy, 50 for Normal, and 75 for Legendary. The points for winning the last-mission would be {{color|blue|500 for Easy}}, {{color|yellow|1000 for Normal}}, and {{color|purple|1500 for Legendary}}. For completing all of the missions once, the sum totals would be {{color|blue|text=Easy = 5,250 points}}, {{color|yellow|text=Normal = 10,500 points}}, and {{color|purple|text=Legendary = 15,750 points}}. Lastly, if each mission were completed all 4 times (with at least 1-hour delays between wins) the total points would be {{color|blue|21,000}}, {{color|yellow|42,000}}, and {{color|purple|63,000}}.
=== Prizes === There are three sets of non-mission-specific prizes available: # Rewards prizes # Ranking prizes (actually two sets: individual and alliance) # Common prizes (aka Mind-meld or 'Thermometer' prizes)
==== Rewards Prizes ==== These are the main type of '''''points''''' prizes. As you work your way through the missions, collecting the mission-prizes, you are also earning points. These points are SOLO efforts that award you prizes based upon how far you go on your own.
The calculations are fairly straightforward (esp with a spreadsheet), but seem a little obscure during gameplay. As mentioned above in Scoring, the number of points you can earn is consistent. If you can wait the required 1-hour between replaying an event, you will maximize your points-earned. The values below assume you play the missions, in order, as expected.
-- put in a bunch of stuff describing the points-to-earn so that on each mission-page the only item needed is the ''one'' prize left to earn... --
==== Ranking Prizes ==== These are actually '''''series''''' prizes. Even though they are also measured using '''''points''''', these prizes are awarded at the conclusion of the event. After all of the other players and all of the other alliances have been tallied up, these prizes will be unlocked. During gameplay, you can see how your progress measures-up againt others. Also, you can see how your team/alliance is compared against other teams. However, I have found that there is little-chance to affect this ranking. Since there are so many other players and teams, the ranking you earn is fairly hard to change. Of course, you still will want to earn your points and encourage your team as well...
There are two-sets of ranking-prizes, the solo efforts (labelled '''Players''') and the team efforts (labelled '''Alliances'''). At the top of the sub-screen, you will see a star-ranking of both YOU and your team... the subtitle for these prizes are '''''Rewards by position''''':
These prizes show up within a day (or at most a week) after the event is concluded as a flashcard onscreen, announcing your rankings (and prizes awarded).
==== 'Thermometer' Prizes ==== These are also a '''''series''''' type of prize. These prizes become a mini-game to play/watch during your progress in each event-level.
These prizes are available by clicking on the horizontal thermometer at the top of the Missions-screen for each sequence (easy/normal/legendary). Once you click into the area, you are presented with the opportunity to "mind meld" with all of the players to attain these prizes. Typically, it takes most of the week (or 2) for the thermometer to fill up enough to activate the bottom-button labelled COLLECT. Unless there is a compelling reason to choose a lower-level, it is usually best to wait until the Legendary prizes are available to be collected.
BEWARE: I have found that once the thermometer is active (ie: the prizes are available to be collected for any screen); then it becmones almost impossible to LEAVE the screen without hitting the collect button. So, if the thermometer is full - and you do not-yet want to collect them; then do not enter the area because there is no back-button afaict. ===== Trivia ===== * Fairly regularly, I have been able to click on COLLECT for the Legendary prizes; and then immediately go to the Normal-section and click again on COLLECT; and then immediately go to the Easy-section and click again on COLLECT. Thus, collecting all three sets of prizes at once. In fact, I think I might have even seen these secondary 'collections' actually doubling their prize outputs !!! OTOH, it is also fairly common to hit COLLECT on one screen and then be denied the ability to Mind-Meld with any of the other-screens. Hence, I always start with the Legendary section, first. * If you are not going to be available to wait until the Legendary prizes are collectable; then it is still worthwhile to mind-meld with a lower-set of prizes, since they are effectively free to collect.

Unlike an Event (from the [[Events Sequence]]), the storyline is fundamentally a series of {{color|blue|text=Easy}} missions designed to get the player used to the game. === Storyline === This is Act '''FIVE''' of the five acts in the [[:Category:Story TNG]] series. ==== '''Trivia''' ==== * tbd... ck=1-10 {{#invoke:EventTables|main|Story |S4..|Race Against Time|The Enterprise and its new Klingon allies return to the destroyed galaxy to prevent catastrophe. |D4..|Approaching Position|Picard gathers Kovor and Kulga in order to design a strategy to defeat the monster. |D4..|Nodroz|A team of Federation members, Klingons and Cardassians reach the sarcophagus room. None imagined what would happen next. |C3..|Last Minute Guest|Among the chaos and confusions, a self-interested Ekoc tips the balance towards the Cardassians. |C4..|Divided!|With the group divided Worf, Riker, and W'Sira must find a way to reunite with the Captains. |C4..|Brothers|Picard and Kulga witness Cardassian family dynamics. |S4..|Storm|Back to the ship, Kulga and W'Sira must fight against Cardassian forces to help the Enterprise. |S4..|Hunt|Worf and Riker try to stop Ekoc's starship before it reaches the dying sun. |D4..|Appeal to Humanity|Picard tries to avoid violence. Surely it's possible to reach a understanding with any intelligent being. |S4..|The Unavoidable End|The Enterprise does everything in its power to buy time for Picard. }} === Enemies === ==== '''Trivia''' ==== * tbd... ck=1-10 {{#invoke:EventTables|main|StoryEnemy |S2|Race Against Time|{{Ships|ncg|..}} | Level 23 c/w-1/0

See: [[:Category:Events]]...
Actually, it is a fairly-useful shortcut that the boxes can be clicked even if they are not foremost in the window... For instance, the yellow-normal version of the event is currently selected in the forefront... To select a different (blue or purple) version, you would normally need to scroll-drag the screen to bring that version to the forefront... However, in reality, you can click on the small edge-of-the-box shown for each level on this current-screen and get to them without needing to do the full drag, first... [[File:Events-main-ARROWSbw-where2click.png|thumb|right|Rather than scroll-drag, just click on the left/EASY or right/HARD box directly...]] {{Menus Navbox}} [[Category:Events]]

==DEFAULT HERO 2 stuff goes in here== [[:Category:Tier 2|Tier two]] characters start at Level '''10''' and max up to Level '''95''' as they are upgraded... Currently, these comprise '''{{#invoke:CommonLists | main | c | count2 }}''' of the {{#invoke:CommonLists | main | c | count0 }} individual character pages. ==tbd...== following characters are still missing basic skills/hp/information: # none ==Trivia== Using the chart/s below, if you receive a character and want to evolve it up using gold coins - then the cumulative costs are: * from 10-12 to 42-50 requires {{P|g|3550|g}} (and {{P|d|22500|x}}) * from level-50 (maxTier_1) on up it might be better to buy yellow-packs with gold... ** a typical yellow-pack for T2 costs {{P|g|3800|g}} and yields 3 to 4 direct upgrades as well as some other-possible-upgrades... ** alternatively, including the upgrade to get to the 50-58 tier, it would cost an additional {{P|g|2600|g}} and {{P|d|70950|x}} to level up completely... (nb - this ignores the 94-95 dilithium if you go by one-at-a-time, otherwise it is {{P|d|73125|x}})
==Skills Updates (Costs)== Tier-2 characters can eventually upgrade all-15 of their possible skills. Yet the first-10 upgrades will only/again get you to the Tier-1 maximum of [[Level 50]], so there is still the element of choice involved. Show/Hide Selling Tier 2 character early
It appears that the cost to level.up (in dilithium) increments by 25 crystals per level... it starts at 75 crystals and by the time you are up around level-50 you need over 1k crystals per level (or another 70k/73k crystals to get to level-95 max from level-50)... of course, you never get your full investment refunded if you sell the high-level characters... (* means ive checked the upgrades with ameh-2) The selling price starts at 125 xtals and increments by 125 for each level of upgrade... Besides just selling at 125 when you have an extra character, there might be a way to maximize-profit by upgrading TWICE (to level-12 by spending 75+100 xtals) and then selling-back (for 375).... This would provide a net-profit of 200 xtals, rather than the straight-sale of 125. However, it is fairly hard to receive level-2 characters and upgrading them completely is usually a better use for them... OTOH, there are indeed a couple of level-2 characters (Kulga, Ameh, ?) that might be suitable for this approach if you haven't already levelled them too high... Specifically, you will only net an extra 75 profit (over the default 125)...

==DEFAULT HERO 1 stuff goes in here== [[:Category:Tier 1|Tier one]] characters start at Level '''one''' and max up to [[Level 50]] as they are upgraded... Currently, these are '''{{#invoke:CommonLists | main | c | count1 }}''' of the {{#invoke:CommonLists | main | c | count0 }} individual character pages. ==tbd...== following characters are still missing basic skills/hp/information: * none
==Skills Updates (Costs)== One subtlety about Tier-1 characters with 3-available skills is that you get to choose which skills to upgrade. Since there are only 10-upgrades vs 15-possibles, then you have the option of generating different versions of the same character. Show/Hide Selling Tier 1 character early
It appears that the cost to level.up (in dilithium) increments by 25 crystals per level... it starts at 100 crystals and by the time you are up around level-30 you need almost 1k crystals per level (or another 20k crystals to get to level-50 max)... of course, you never get your full investment refunded if you sell the high-level characters... (* means ive checked the upgrades with chekov-1) The selling price starts at 75 xtals and increments by 75 for each level of upgrade... Besides just selling at 75 when you have an extra character, there might be a way to maximize-profit by upgrading ONCE (to level-2 by spending 100 xtals) and then selling-back (for 150).... Nope, you would only receive 50 profit for your investment, whereas just selling outright initially nets you 75 xtals profit...

==DEFAULT HERO 3 stuff goes in here== [[:Category:Tier 3|Tier three]] characters start at Level '''40''' and max up to Level '''165''' as they are upgraded... Currently, these comprise '''{{#invoke:CommonLists | main | c | count3 }}''' of the {{#invoke:CommonLists | main | c | count0 }} individual character pages. ==tbd...== following characters are still missing basic skills/hp/information: * none also, i am missing photos for: * none ==Trivia== Using the chart/s below, if you receive a character and want to evolve it up using gold coins - then the cumulative costs are: * from 40-42 to 44-50 only requires {{P|g|550|g}} (and {{P|d|1625|x}})... * from level-50 (maxTier_1) to the next-plateau at level-96 (maxTier_2) breaks out as follows: ** from 44-50 (NOT 50-58) tier, it requires an additional {{P|g|3100|g}} and {{P|d|39675|x}}... ** usually, it is easier/more-convenient to spend the first 350-coins before accumulating the remaining 2750... ** random comments about sorting the possibly long-list of crew (if you have purchased enough slots to hold them)... *** since ALL characters have a stopping-point at level-50, it can be a bit tricky to see them sorted in a way that makes-sense... *** since the crew is sorted by level, i find it easier to evolve both T2 and T3 crew once more beyond maxTier_1 into the 50-58 evolution... *** this allows T3 crew to be upgraded to level-53 (for example) so they stand-out among any T1 or T2 crew that is stuck at level-50... *** also, i can upgrade T2 crew to level-52 (for example) so they also stand-out beyond the T1 crew that is stuck at level-50... *** however, once upgraded completely for evolution-9, any T3 crew are easy to track because they are at level-96, rather than the actual maxTier_2 (for T2 crew) of level-95... * this brings us to the final evolution/upgrade sequence for maxTier_3... ** personally, i find it more-useful to complete the evolutions (without spending the dilithium to upgrade to the higher-levels) first... ** now, a typical yellow-pack for T3 costs {{P|g|4800|g}} (or sometimes 5200) and yields 3 to 4 direct upgrades as well as some other-possible-upgrades... ** alternatively, including the upgrade to get to the 96-104 tier, it would cost an additional {{P|g|6300|g}} and {{P|d|158700|x}}... (can reduce by 3150 xtals if go up-by-ones)...
==Skills Updates (Costs)== Tier-3 characters can eventually upgrade all-15 of their possible skills. There are two natural stages of upgrades. The first stage is at [[Level 50]], and happens after only 3 evolutions. The second stage is at [[Level 95]], and happens after 9 (not 10) upgrades. Technically, the 9th evolution goes up to '''''Level 96''''' but we can assume that these two levels (95 and 96) are the same for effective battles between items. To be clear, the '''Category''' will be called [[:Category:Level95]] even if the Tier-3 character will have its ''data'' from level-96... Overall, there is still the element of choice involved for these first few upgrades. Show/Hide Selling Tier 3 character early
The selling price starts at 250 xtals and increments by 250 for each level of upgrade... Besides just selling at 250 when you have an extra character, there is probably a way to maximize-profit by upgrading a set number of times. To be fair, I have not yet received enough Level-3 characters to have ever actually had occasion to sell one... However, for the sake of argument - we can analyze: * Assuming we have only one spare tier-3 character... ** Selling outright nets 250 xtals pure profit ** Upgrading twice to level 42 costs 125, but selling yields 750, for net of 625 profit * Assuming we have two spares of the same tier-3 character... ** Selling outright nets 500 xtals pure profit ** Upgrading one spare to level 42 and then selling it (for each one) nets 1250 profit - assuming you do not want to keep the tier-3 character in your inventory at all... ** Upgrading the first spare to level 42, then evolving it using the second spare, and then upgrading it to level 44, will yield: cost 350, sale 1250, net profit 900... this is less profit than doing them separately yielded. ** Upgrading one spare to level 42 then using 250-gold and upgrading to level 44 would yield 1250-225=1025 xtals and 250-gold... doing this twice (per-char) yields 2050 xtals profit (or conversion of 500-gold)... xtals are MUCH cheaper to reap than gold, so this will not be a useful return-on-investment either... * Assuming we have three spares... ** Selling outright nets 750 ** Upgrading each to 42 and selling nets 1875 profit (BEST-CASE-HERE) ** Upgrading one to 42, evolving, upgrading to 44, evolving, and then upgrading to 47 would cost (1625-750 = 875), while the sale gives 2000, yielding 1125 profit. ** Overall the diminishing returns aspect seems to show that evolving is not worth it, especially if you plan to sell anyway - similar to the tier-2 case... Again, it is unlikely that a person would have over 15 Tier-3 characters to try this experiment with. Otherwise, for battle and inventory uses, it is better to have a fully-evolved and upgraded Tier-3 character (at level 165) than it would be to just be trying to sell for the minor crystals gains involved. OTOH, i have seen one player online who had two Tier-3 characters of the same name (different ranks, but one fully-evolved and upgraded) so i guess it is/was possible... Also, i believe the rules of the game (now) do not allow a person to have two-copies of the same character in your inventory - hence the choices involved with Tier-1 characters.

there is a very-cool-trick to sort by multiple-columns... for instance, lets say that you want to sort the heroes by following columns, in order: TOS/TNG, then TIER, then hp (or key-name/letters) - you would do this: # left-click column-TOS/TNG (if you did this multiple times, it will alternate between ascending and descending alphabetically... # once the first-column is 'in order', then to get the next column sorted you type/hold the '''''SHIFT''''' key while selecting (left-click) on second-column - ie: TIER... # once the first AND second-columns are 'in order', continue to hold the '''''SHIFT''''' key while selecting (left-click) on your third-choice - ie: hp (or key)... this secret of holding '''''SHIFT''''' while multi-selecting columns will allow you to order the sortable-wikitable in any fashion you'd like... hth, h. Reference: [http://meta.wikimedia.org/wiki/Help%3aSorting#Secondary_sortkey secondary sorting]

==DEFAULT SHIP 1 stuff goes in here== [[:Category:Tier 1|Tier one]] Starships start at Level '''one''' and max up to [[Level 50]] as they are upgraded... Currently, these are '''{{#invoke:CommonLists | main | s | count1 }}''' of the {{#invoke:CommonLists | main | s | count0 }} individual starship pages. These ships can have up to 4 crew members and 4 weapons... When they start at level-1, they do not have any slots for crew or weapons available... At level-10, they get one-slot of each... Their max-amounts (4 of each) happen at the upgrade to level-45 and maintain thru their final max-level of 50... ==tbd...== following starships are still missing basic skills/hp/information: * none
==Crew/Weapons Updates (Costs)== This info mirrors the costs for Tier-1 characters (incl sell). Specifically, the cost to level up (from lvl-1 to lvl-2) starts at 100 crystals. Each successive level of upgrade costs an extra 25 crystals (lvl-2 to lvl-3 is 125, then 150, etc...). For the details per-level see: [[Test_Hero_Level_1_type#Skills_Updates_.28Costs.29|here]]... note: crew/weapons increases and costs confirmed (* = RBP) {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center;" border="1" |- ! scope="col" | Beg. ==DEFAULT SHIP 3 stuff goes in here== [[:Category:Tier 3|Tier three]] Starships start at Level '''40''' and max up to Level '''165''' as they are upgraded... Currently, these comprise '''{{#invoke:CommonLists | main | s | count3 }}''' of the {{#invoke:CommonLists | main | s | count0 }} individual starship pages. These ships can have up to 8 (d5=6c+7w/bc2=7+7) crew members and 8 weapons... At the beginning (level 40), there are usually 2 slots for each... At level 50, there are (also, USUALLY) 2 slots for each... At level 96, there are 4 slots for each... Beyond level 96, the number of slots can vary per-ship/type which will need to be documented better... ==tbd...== following starships are still missing basic skills/hp/information: * none these are just missing photos * none
==Crew/Weapons Updates (Costs)== The upgrade-levels are the same as Tier-3 characters, but the upgrade costs are oddly equivalent to the Tier-2 starships... see:[[Test_Ship_Level_2_type#Crew.2FWeapons Updates_.28Costs.29|here]] The data thru Level-96 is accurate, but some of the details at higher-levels is still theoretical...
